flags.title: Unlimited Liability Exposure
flags.description: The contract does not contain a limitation of liability clause, exposing QDB to potentially unlimited damages in case of breach or other claims.
flags.recommendation: Insert a limitation of liability clause that caps total damages to a reasonable amount, such as a multiple of fees paid or a fixed sum, and excludes certain types of damages (e.g., consequential, indirect).

flags.title: Intellectual Property Ownership Ambiguity
flags.description: The contract does not explicitly state that QDB will own the intellectual property rights in any deliverables created by the Supplier. This could lead to disputes over ownership.
flags.recommendation: Add a clause stating that all intellectual property developed by the Supplier for QDB under this agreement will be owned by QDB.

flags.title: Missing Indemnification Clause
flags.description: The contract lacks an indemnification clause, meaning neither party is contractually obligated to defend or reimburse the other for certain third-party claims (e.g., IP infringement, negligence).
flags.recommendation: Include mutual indemnification clauses where each party agrees to indemnify the other against losses arising from their breach of contract or specific actions (e.g., Supplier indemnifies QDB against IP infringement claims related to deliverables).

flags.title: Missing Confidentiality/Non-Disclosure Clause
flags.description: There is no clause protecting confidential information exchanged between QDB and Vendor Inc. This leaves sensitive data vulnerable.
flags.recommendation: Incorporate a confidentiality clause that defines confidential information and obligates the receiving party to protect it, specifying the duration of the obligation.

flags.title: Missing Termination Rights Clause
flags.description: The agreement does not outline the conditions under which either party can terminate the contract, leading to uncertainty and potential lock-in.
flags.recommendation: Add termination clauses allowing for termination for cause (e.g., material breach) and for convenience (with appropriate notice period and potential termination fees).

flags.title: Missing Dispute Resolution Clause
flags.description: The contract does not specify how disputes will be resolved, which can lead to costly and time-consuming litigation.
flags.recommendation: Include a dispute resolution clause outlining steps such as negotiation, mediation, arbitration, or litigation, and specifying the venue.

flags.title: Missing Force Majeure Clause
flags.description: The absence of a force majeure clause means neither party has a defined mechanism to be excused from performance due to unforeseen events beyond their control.
flags.recommendation: Add a force majeure clause that lists specific events (e.g., natural disasters, war, pandemics) that excuse performance and outlines the procedure for invoking it.

flags.title: Governing Law Alignment
flags.description: The contract states the governing law is 'laws of Qatar'. This aligns with the target jurisdiction, but lacks specificity (e.g., 'federal laws of Qatar').
flags.recommendation: Clarify 'laws of Qatar' to specify 'federal laws of the State of Qatar' to avoid ambiguity.

flags.title: Extended Payment Window Risk
flags.description: A net 60-day payment term upon completion of services might be challenging for supplier cash flow and could incentivize delays if not strictly managed by QDB.
flags.recommendation: Consider negotiating a shorter payment term (e.g., net 30) or milestone-based payments for significant project stages to improve cash flow predictability and incentivize timely delivery.

flags.title: Ambiguous Service Deliverables
flags.description: The contract mentions 'completion of services' but lacks a detailed scope of work or specific deliverables, making it difficult to assess performance and trigger payment.
flags.recommendation: Attach a detailed Statement of Work (SOW) or Scope of Services as an exhibit to the agreement, clearly defining all deliverables, acceptance criteria, and timelines.

flags.title: Missing Data Protection Clause
flags.description: While GDPR is not directly applicable as the parties are Qatari entities, the contract lacks any general data privacy clauses regarding the handling of personal information, which is a best practice.
flags.recommendation: Include a clause outlining the parties' obligations regarding the processing and protection of any personal data they may encounter during the contract's performance, in accordance with Qatari data protection principles.

recommendations: Insert a limitation of liability clause that caps total damages to a reasonable amount, such as a multiple of fees paid or a fixed sum, and excludes certain types of damages (e.g., consequential, indirect).
